subject: Education
title: Waldorf Schools: No Screens, No Tests
description: A 1-minute de-risking session on Waldorf Schools: No Screens, No Tests.

hook.text: Waldorf schools ban screens, delay reading until age 7, and have kids knit in class. There are 1,200 worldwide.

buildup.text: Rudolf Steiner created Waldorf education in 1919 for factory workers' children. He believed in educating the whole

discovery.text: Students paint, garden, and play instruments before they open a textbook. Creativity comes first, academics second.

twist.text: Critics call it anti-science. Steiner's spiritual philosophy included some strange ideas about race and reincarnation.

climax.text: Waldorf graduates score well on creativity measures. The method survives because parents see happier, more curious kids.

punchline.text: No screens, no tests, no rush. Just childhood.

quiz.question: At what age do Waldorf schools typically begin formal reading instruction?
